Friesz b ⁎ tfriesz@psu.edu Tao Yao b tyy1@engr.psu.edu a Department of Mathematics, Pennsylvania State University, PA 16802, USA b Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, PA 16802, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +1 814 863 2445. Highlights ► The Vickrey model is described by an ordinary differential equation with discontinuous right hand side. ► The Vickrey model is reformulated as a scalar conservation law. ► Closed-form solutions of the above ODE and PDE are obtained via PDE theory. ► The generalized Vickrey model is proposed, which allows flow to be a distribution. ► The Vickrey model is related to the LWR model through the PDE formulation. Abstract This paper is concerned with the continuous-time Vickrey model, which was first introduced in Vickrey (1969). This model can be described by an ordinary differential equation (ODE) with a right-hand side which is discontinuous in the unknown variable. Such a formulation induces difficulties with both theoretical analysis and numerical computation. Moreover it is widely suspected that an explicit solution to this ODE does not exist. In this paper, we advance the knowledge and understanding of the continuous-time Vickrey model by reformulating it as a partial differential equation (PDE) and by applying a variational method to obtain an explicit solution representation. Such an explicit solution is then shown to be the strong solution to the ODE in full mathematical rigor. Our methodology also leads to the notion of generalized Vickrey model (GVM), which allows the flow to be a distribution, instead of an integrable function. As explained by Han et al. (in press), this feature of traffic modeling is desirable in the context of analytical dynamic traffic assignment (DTA). The proposed PDE formulation provides new insights into the physics of The Vickrey model, which leads to a number of modeling extensions as well as connection with first-order traffic models such as the Lighthill–Whitham–Richards (LWR) model. The explicit solution representation also leads to a new computational method, which will be discussed in an accompanying paper, Han et al. (in press). Keywords Continuous-time Vickrey model Ordinary differential equation Partial differential equation Explicit solution The Lax–Hopf formula 1 Introduction 1.1 General background and modeling issue The Vickrey Model (VM) is one of the most commonly employed link models in the current literature on dynamic traffic assignment. It was original presented in Vickrey (1969) and discussed subsequently, for example, by Drissi-Kat¨ouni and Hameda-Benchekroun (1992), Heydecker and Addison (1996), Kuwahara and Akamatsu (1997), and Li et al. (2000). The Vickrey model is based on the assumption that the queue has negligible size and that the travel time on the link consists of a free-flow travel time plus a congestion related queuing time. A popular mathematical form of the model is an ordinary differential equation with discontinuous dependence on the state variable. Such an irregularity leads to several theoretical difficulties: a classical solution may no longer exist; and it is widely suspected that such an ODE does not admit an explicit solution representation. For a general review on ODEs with discontinuous state-dependence, the reader is referred to Filippov (1988) and Stewart (1990). Subsequent research based on the Vickrey model mainly focuses on two aspects: (1) modification of the original model in continuous-time, and (2) discrete-time counterpart of the model. The first line of research is primarily represented by the work of Armbruster et al. (2006a), Ban et al. (2011), and Pang et al. (2011). In the study of a dynamic user equilibrium (DUE) problem with a single bottleneck, Pang et al. (2011) used a linear complementarity system (LCS) as an approximation to the Vickrey model. Such an LCS does not admit an explicit ODE representation. Nevertheless, it was shown in Ban et al. (2011) that the LCS yields an absolutely continuous solution that satisfies the complementarity condition almost everywhere. In an attempt to approximate the LCS with an explicit ODE, Ban et al. (2011) proposed the α-model which includes a smoothing parameter α ≫1. The α-model has an explicit ODE representation. Moreover, it exhibits an asymptotic behavior as α approaches infinity, and the limit is precisely the LCS studied in Pang et al. (2011). The point-queue type dynamic has been employed also in the context of continuous supply chain networks. Armbruster et al. (2006a) considered an ODE similar to the α-model: that ODE also contains a smoothing parameter 0< ε ≪1. Such a system, which we will subsequently call the ε-model, has been verified extensively against the deterministic discrete event simulations (DDES) by Armbruster et al. (2006b). Notice that all of the aforementioned continuous-time models deviate from Vickrey’s original model, in exchange for the theoretical and computational convenience. In addition, the smoothing parameters introduced by the α-model and the ε-model need to be further understood in terms of their underlying physical meanings and modeling implications. A more detailed review of these models is provided by this paper, in Section 3. So far, the Vickrey model or the point-queue type models are mainly studied in discrete time and in a numerical framework. Yet, fundamental issues regarding convergence and physical realism of the numerical solutions remain relatively less understood. Ban et al. (2011) showed that both forward and backward finite-difference schemes for the Vickrey ODE may yield negative queue lengths and/or negative flows. A few adaptations of the finite-difference algorithms that would avoid the above problems were proposed, for example, by Armbruster et al. (2006a), Ban et al. (2011), and Pang et al. (2011). However, these improved algorithms still bear certain numerical limitations. For example, the α-model by Ban et al. (2011) could potentially lead to negative queues if a forward scheme is used. Furthermore, the forward scheme of the α-model exhibits conditional stability. The ε-model by Armbruster et al. (2006a) could potentially lead to non-physical solutions in some rare circumstances, see Han et al. (2012b) for an example. One should notice that the performances of both the α-model and the ε-model are greatly influenced by the smoothing parameters chosen, which could potentially add to the complexity and uncertainty of the corresponding dynamical system. In view of the above limitations, a mathematically rigorous investigation of the original Vickrey’s model in continuous time will not only provide new insights into the physics of the model, but also plow new grounds for the analysis and computation of the Vickrey model in the context of DTA. This motivates our two-part work. 1.2 Methodology based on partial differential equations It has not been noted before that one may analyze the Vickrey model from the approach of partial differential equations. The PDEs are playing important roles in hydrodynamic traffic flow models such as the Lighthill–Whitham–Richards model by Lighthill and Whitham (1955) and Richards (1956). A list of selected references on the LWR model is Bressan and Han (2011a,b), Claudel and Bayen (2010a,b), Daganzo (1994, 1995, 2005), Garavello and Piccoli (2006), Han et al. (2012c), and Newell (1993). The PDE formulation of the Vickrey model is motivated by the simple observation that the Vickrey model, like many hydrodynamic models, is based on conservation of cars. Such a principle manifests itself in the generic form (1.1) ∂ t ρ ( t , x ) + ∂ x f ( t , x ) = 0 where ρ(t, x) and f(t, x) denotes respectively the density and flow at time t and location x. The spatial dimension in (1.1) can be naturally embedded in the Vickrey model due to the presence of a free-flow phase (although our analysis presented in this paper works even if the free-flow time is zero). The bottleneck located at the exit of a link can be modeled by an x-dependent flow capacity constraint imposed on the entire link. This requires that the flow is not only a function of density (which is the case for LWR model), but also a function of the spatial variable x. A more detailed and formal discussion based on the above observations can be found in Section 4.1. Once a conservation law describing the point-queue dynamic of the Vickrey model is obtained, we can readily derive a Hamilton–Jacobi equation by integrating the scalar conservation law. The key component of our analysis is a variational method for the H–J equation, which is known as the Lax–Hopf formula (Bressan and Han, 2011a; Daganzo, 2005; Evans, 2010; Le Floch, 1988; Lax, 1957). The Lax–Hopf formula was originally proposed as a semi-analytic representation of the solutions to the scalar conservation law and the Hamilton–Jacobi equation. Its application to first-order traffic flow models are recently investigated by Aubin et al. (2008), Bressan and Han (2011a,b), Claudel and Bayen (2010a,b), and Daganzo (2005). The variational approach expresses the viscosity solution to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation as an optimization problem. However, note that the Lax–Hopf formula does not immediately apply to because the Hamiltonian of our derived H–J equation has a discontinuous dependence on the spatial variable x. As a consequence, the H–J equation does not admit solutions in the viscosity sense, see Evans (2010) for more details. In other words, one can only expect the solution to be defined in the distributional sense, i.e. the density ρ(t, x) can contain dirac-delta which is precisely the mathematical abstraction of the “point queue”. Fortunately, as we show in this paper, it is possible to apply the Lax–Hopf formula in a novel way even though the resulting density is a distribution. Technical detail of the analysis is presented in Section 4.2. 1.3 Findings and contributions The proposed PDE approach provides a new level of understanding of the physics of the Vickrey model and other point-queue type models. Moreover, by applying PDE theory and solution technique, we are able to derive explicit solutions to the Vickrey ODE (1.2) dq ( t ) dt = u ( t - t 0 ) - min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) ≠ 0 where q(·) denotes the queue size; u(·) denotes the link inflow which is given as input of the model; M is the flow capacity; t 0 is the free flow time. As we will show in Theorem 5.2, the strong solution (or integral solution) to the ODE (1.2) is given explicitly as (1.3) q ( t ) = ∫ - ∞ t - t 0 u ( s ) ds - M ( t - t 0 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 ∫ - ∞ τ u ( s ) ds - M τ This paper also provides mathematical analysis on the solution given by (1.3). We have investigated analytical properties of the solution pertaining to physical realism, regularity and first-in-first-out (FIFO). Detailed results are presented in Proposition 4.12. The ODE representation of the Vickrey model requires that the inflow u(·) is Lebesgue integrable. Equivalently, the cumulative entering vehicle count U ( t ) ≐ ∫ - ∞ t u ( s ) ds is required to be absolutely continuous. In this paper, the above assumptions are relaxed in a way that u(·) can contain δ-distribution and U(·) can be discontinuous. This is achieved by working with the cumulative vehicle counts, also known as the Newell-curves (Newell, 1993), and by applying the explicit solution obtained from the Lax–Hopf formula. The resulting model, which we will call the generalized Vickrey model (GVM), can handle cumulative entering vehicle count with up to countably many jumps. The GVM reduces to the original Vickrey model provided that the cumulative entering vehicle count is absolutely continuous. In the study of analytical DTA, such an extension is desirable as it guarantees the existence of certain system optimal and user equilibrium solutions: Bressan and Han (2011a) presented a dynamic user equilibrium (DUE) problem whose solution exists only when the cumulative departure curve is discontinuous; in Han et al. (in press), the proof of existence of a class of system optimal solutions relies on the assumption that the arc entering vehicle count can be discontinuous. The proposed PDE formulation leads to a number of extensions of the Vickrey model that will be discussed in Section 7. By modifying the flux function (Hamiltonian) of the conservation law (H–J equation), we are able to consider road inhomogeneity and time-varying flow capacity. Insights on the solution existence and on the mathematical properties of these extended models are provided as well. In addition, we discuss the relationship of the Vickrey model with the LWR model via a comparison of their respective fundamental diagrams. To sum up, the contributions of this article are as follows. 1. We formulate the continuous-time Vickrey model first as a scalar conservation law and then a Hamilton–Jacobi equation. Such formulations shed light on the physics of the Vickrey model and provides insights on its relationship with the LWR model. 2. We apply a variational method to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation and derive an explicit solution. This leads to the explicit solution of the ODE with discontinuous right hand side. 3. We establish and analyze the mathematical properties of the closed-form solutions mentioned in item 2 above, pertaining to physical realism, regularity and first-in-first-out. 4. We introduce the generalized Vickrey model. The GVM provides all the variables of interest in closed form. Furthermore, it does not invoke any differential equations and allows the entering flow to be a distribution. The generalized Vickrey model proposed in this paper is convenient for the analysis of network models, which arise from the context of dynamic traffic assignment. Han et al. (2012a) used the GVM to show the continuity of the so-called effective delay operator embedded in the notion of dynamic user equilibrium first articulated by Friesz et al. (1993). Such an analytical result would be difficult to establish if based on the ODE formulation. 1.4 Organization The rest of this article is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the Vickrey model and its ODE formulation. Section 3 reports several continuous-time modifications of the Vickrey model, proposed in Armbruster et al. (2006a), Ban et al. (2011), and Pang et al. (2011). In Section 4, we reformulate the Vickrey model as a partial differential equation, and apply the variational method to solve it. An explicit solution is obtained as a result. In Section 5, we focus on the original ODE problem and show that the solution obtained from Section 4 indeed solves the ODE with discontinuous right hand side. Section 6 presents the generalized Vickrey model which allows for a more general network flow profile. In Section 7, several extensions of the Vickrey model are discussed based on our PDE formulation. Further insights on the relationship between the Vickrey model and the LWR model are provided. Finally, Section 8 presents two examples that illustrate the unique features of the closed-form solutions put forward in this paper. 2 Review of the Vickrey model The Vickrey model (Vickrey, 1969) is based on two primary assumptions: (1) the vehicles have negligible sizes, queues do not occupy any physical spaces; and (2) the link traversal time consists of a fixed travel time plus a congestion-related queuing time. This model takes various mathematical forms in the literature, for example in Drissi-Kat¨ouni and Hameda-Benchekroun (1992), Heydecker and Addison (1996), Kuwahara and Akamatsu (1997), and Li et al. (2000). One of the most recognized formulations is discussed by Kuwahara and Akamatsu (1997) and Nie and Zhang (2005), which we present here and use as a starting point of our analysis. Let us introduce the following notations. u(t) the link entering flow w(t) the link exiting flow q(t) the queue size M the flow capacity of the bottleneck t 0 the free flow travel time λ(t) the link traversal time of drivers entering the link at t Consider a time horizon [0, T], with any T >0. The link flow dynamic can be described as follows. (1) Vehicles entering the link move with free flow speed before arriving at the exit, which is a bottleneck; and (2) a queue with zero physical size (point queue) forms at the exit if the arriving flow exceeds the bottleneck capacity. The rate at which vehicles are released from the queue is described by (2.4) w ( t ) = min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) > 0 t 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T The rule for releasing vehicles from the queue is straightforward: vehicles are released at maximum rate allowed by the link capacity and vehicles supplied to the queue. Once the flow arriving at the queue u(t − t 0) and the flow leaving the queue w(t) are determined, the change rate of the queue can be described by (2.5) dq ( t ) dt = 0 if 0 ⩽ t < t 0 u ( t - t 0 ) - w ( t ) if t 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T By (2.5), it is assumed that the link is empty at t =0. Notice that if the queue is nonempty, then the time it takes to traverse this queue is proportional to q(t). Therefore, for a driver entering the link at t, the link traversal time can be expressed as (2.6) λ ( t ) = t 0 + q ( t + t 0 ) M 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T The Vickrey model is described collectively by (2.4)–(2.6). Notice that (2.4) and (2.5) can be combined to form a single ordinary differential equation (2.7) dq ( t ) dt = u ( t - t 0 ) - min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) > 0 t 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T The case when 0⩽ t ⩽ t 0 is trivial since the queue remains empty. One important observation is that the right hand side of ODE (2.7) is discontinuous in the unknown variable q(t). To see this, consider the case where q(t)>0 and u(t − t 0)< M. As q(t) approaches zero, the exit flow w(t) will jump from M down to u(t − t 0). Such a discontinuous dependence implies that the ODE (2.7) does not have any classical solution, i.e. solutions that are locally continuously differentiable. Instead, one may consider the solution in the integral sense, i.e. solution that satisfies the differential equation at almost every t ∈[0, T]; or more generally, solution in the distributional (weak) sense. 3 Modifications of the Vickrey model Due to the irregularity within the ODE, a direct analysis of the aforementioned Vickrey model in continuous-time is difficult: one needs to rely on the mathematical tools for discontinuous ODEs, for example, Filippov (1988) and Stewart (1990). However, a few modifications of the Vickrey model have been proposed in the literature that allow further analysis of the dynamics in continuous-time. In this section, we will briefly review these models with some minor discussions. 3.1 Linear complementarity system formulation (Pang et al., 2011) In the study of a DUE problem with a single bottleneck, Pang et al. (2011) used a time-dependent linear complementarity system (LCS) as an alternative to the ODE (2.7). The LSC can be explicitly written as (3.8) dq ( t ) dt = s ( t ) + u ( t - t 0 ) - M (3.9) 0 ⩽ s ( t ) ⊥ q ( t ) ⩾ 0 Here s(t) is a time-dependent slack variable, the rest of the notations are same as before. System (3.8) and (3.9) does not admit an explicit ODE formulation but has the implicit ODE form (3.10) min q ( t ) , dq ( t ) dt + M - u ( t - t 0 ) = 0 The LCS model explicitly imposes the non-negativity of the queue size q(t). As mentioned in Ban et al. (2011), this model deviates from Vickrey’s original model in the case when q(t)=0. Indeed, the Vickrey model implies in this case that dq ( t ) dt = max { u ( t - t 0 ) - M , 0 } , while (3.10) merely implies dq ( t ) dt ⩾ u ( t - t 0 ) - M . As far as finite-difference schemes for (3.8) and (3.9) are concerned, a forward (explicit) scheme is not well-defined. Namely, given the state variables at current time step, the state variables at the next time step are underdetermined. See Ban et al. (2011) for more detail. However, a backward (implicit) scheme is well-defined and coincides with the numerical scheme proposed in Nie and Zhang (2005). In addition, the non-negativity of the queue length is guaranteed under such a scheme because of (3.9). 3.2 The α-model (Ban et al., 2011) Ban et al. (2011) proposed a novel approach which transformed the above LCS into an explicit ODE. This was done by introducing a parameter α ≫1 and by writing (3.11) dq ( t ) dt = max { u ( t - t 0 ) - M , - α q ( t ) } Hereafter, we refer to the above equation as the α-model, a name suggested in Ban et al. (2011). It has been shown by Ban et al. (2011) that the continuous-time solution to (3.11) guarantees the non-negativity of both queue size and exit flow, through some non-trivial argument. Moreover, as α →+∞, the solution of ODE (3.11) converges to the solution of the LCS above. However, we note that the α-model also deviates from the Vickrey model: if q(t)≠0 and u(t − t 0)− M + αq(t)<0, then dq ( t ) dt = - α q ( t ) > u ( t - t 0 ) - M while the Vickrey model and the LCS both stipulate that dq ( t ) dt = u ( t - t 0 ) - M . Regarding numerical performance of the model, it was demonstrated in Ban et al. (2011) that an explicit (forward) discretization scheme for the α-model may result in negative queues. Moreover, the stability of the explicit scheme is conditional. On the other hand, the implicit (backward) scheme ensures the non-negativity of the queue and the flow while approximating the LCS model well if the value of α is appropriately selected. The remaining question for the α-model is how to appropriately select the numerical values of α to ensure the proper functioning of this model. In a dynamic and complex network setting where the flows on each link are highly variable, the selection of α is crucial. Furthermore, it is interesting to further explore the physical meaning and the underlying modeling implications of the parameter α. 3.3 The ε-model (Armbruster et al., 2006a) Models that rely on the point-queue type dynamics appear also in the modeling of continuous supply chains networks. In particular, Armbruster et al. (2006a) and Fügenschuh et al. (2008) employed the following link dynamic, which is very similar to that of the Vickrey model. (3.12) d dt q ( t ) = u ( t ) - min { u ( t ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) ≠ 0 Notice that (3.12) implies that the queue of goods/products is located at the entrance of each link (processor), instead of at the exit. In order to smooth out the discontinuity in the right hand side of ODE (3.12), a smoothing parameter 0< ε ≪1 was used so that (3.12) became (3.13) d dt q ( t ) = u ( t ) - min M , q ( t ) ε Hereafter, we call (3.13) the ε-model. We observe that the ODE (3.13) is stiff whenever 0< q(t)< εM. A stiffness condition needs to be imposed for the explicit scheme to ensure stability. (3.14) Δ t ⩽ ε where Δt denotes the time step size of the discretization. The ε-model and the α-model share a similar mathematical structure. Such an assertion is supported by the following slightly different presentation of (3.13): (3.15) d dt q ( t ) = max u ( t ) - M , 1 ε ( ε u ( t ) - q ( t ) ) where ε can be treated as 1/α. In regimes where α is large or ε is small, the systems (3.15) and (3.11) tend to exhibit the same qualitative behavior. The ε-model has a an explicit ODE representation. It is a practical alternative to (3.12), as was verified extensively in Armbruster et al. (2006a) against deterministic discrete event simulations. However, the solution quality deteriorates for relatively large values of ε. One such example has been demonstrated in Han et al. (2012b). In view of (3.14), there is a trade-off between numerical stability and/or computational efficiency, and the solution quality. We note here that both the α-model and the ε-model rely on an appropriate choice of an exogenous parameter, which is influenced by the numerical scales of variables such as t, q(t) and u(t). Such a fact could potentially raise the issue of scalability of these models. In other words, a case-dependent strategy for choosing the parameters is necessary to ensure the overall performance of these models. 3.4 summary This section presents three continuous-time alternatives to the Vickrey model. Each model have its own merits in analysis and application. The alternative models approximate the Vickrey model under certain conditions, and the corresponding numerical methods manage to fix the problems arising from the time-discretization of the original Vickrey ODE. In addition, the approximate formulations provide valuable analytical and computational insights of the Vickrey model. Unlike the aforementioned work, this paper aims to directly tackle the Vickrey ODE in continuous-time and to provide further insights of the model from the view point of partial differential equations. 4 A partial differential equation formulation of the Vickrey model In this section, we reformulate the Vickrey model with a partial differential equation. This novel approach provides unique insights and analytical tools that are unavailable through theoretical or numerical study of the ODE. 4.1 A PDE model Recall the Vickrey model in the form of an ordinary differential equation (4.16) dq ( t ) dt = u ( t - t 0 ) - w ( t ) , q ( t 0 ) = 0 t 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T + t 0 (4.17) w ( t ) = 0 0 ⩽ t ⩽ t 0 min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) > 0 t 0 < t ⩽ T + t 0 (4.18) λ ( t ) = q ( t + t 0 ) M + t 0 0 ⩽ t ⩽ T The key ingredient of a PDE reformulation of system (4.16)–(4.18) is a virtual spatial dimension x ∈[0, L], where L is the link length. We introduce free flow speed v 0 such that L = v 0 t 0. Similar to the LWR model, the Vickrey model can be described based on conservation of mass (4.19) ∂ t ρ ( t , x ) + ∂ x f ( t , x ) = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ] where ρ(t, x), f(t, x) denotes respectively the vehicle density and flow at a point in the temporal-spatial domain. Notice that a PDE of the form (4.19) is always true for any dynamics prescribed by the conservation of mass. What distinguishes the Vickrey model from the LWR model is the density-flow relationship. In the classical LWR model, flow is a function of density only, which is given by the fundamental diagram. While in the Vickrey model, the flow depends not only on density but also on the spatial variable x, due to the presence of a bottleneck at the link exit x = L. Indeed, the flow f(t, x) can be expressed via a flux function ϕ (4.20) f ( t , x ) = ϕ ( x , ρ ( t , x ) ) ≐ v 0 ρ ( t , x ) if x ∈ [ 0 , L ) min { M , v 0 ρ ( t , x ) } if x = L Another way of interpreting the flux function ϕ is as follows. We introduce the x-dependent capacity function M ( x ) , which is defined as (4.21) M ( x ) ≐ + ∞ if x ∈ [ 0 , L ) M if x = L The definition above is quite straightforward: in the free flow phase x ∈[0, L), vehicles always travel at a constant speed no matter how large the flow may be, implying the flow capacity is infinite; whereas at the exit x = L, a finite capacity constraint applies. The flux function ϕ can be alternatively defined as (4.22) ϕ ( x , ρ ( t , x ) ) = min { M ( x ) , v 0 ρ ( t , x ) } which explicitly imposes the flow capacity constraint everywhere. On can easily check that the two definitions (4.20) and (4.22) of ϕ are equivalent. Summarizing what is discussed, we present the conservation law formulation of the Vickrey model (4.23) ∂ t ρ ( t , x ) + ∂ x min { M ( x ) , v 0 ρ ( t , x ) } = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ] v 0 ρ ( t , 0 ) = u ( t ) t ∈ [ 0 , T ] where M ( x ) is given by (4.21), u(t) is the link inflow. Remark 4.1 Eq. (4.23) is a scalar conservation law with x-dependent flux function. A review of mathematical results on this type of PDEs can be found in Evans (2010). Notice that due to the discontinuous dependence of the flux function on x, the solution to the PDE (4.23) can only be considered in the distributional sense. In other words, ρ(t, x) may contain δ-distribution, which is a mathematical abstraction of the notion of “point queue”. 1 For this reason, many scholars refer to the Vickrey model as the point queue model (PQM). However, the authors of this paper are reluctant to use this name since the name PQM was first suggested by Daganzo (1994) to describe the link delay model (LDM) proposed by Friesz et al. (1993). 1 Next, we present the Hamilton–Jacobi equation which is obtained by integrating the conservation law (4.23). Let us introduce the cumulative vehicle counts (4.24) N ( t , x ) ≐ ∫ 0 t f ( s , x ) ds , U ( t ) ≐ ∫ 0 t u ( s ) ds t ∈ [ 0 , T ] , x ∈ [ 0 , L ] N(t, x), commonly called the Newell-curve (Newell, 1993), measures the number of vehicles that have passed location x by time t. U(·)≡ N(·,0) is the cumulative entering vehicle count. N(·,·) satisfies the following Hamilton–Jacobi equation. (4.25) ∂ t N ( t , x ) - min { M ( x ) , - v 0 ∂ x N ( t , x ) } = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ] N ( t , 0 ) = U ( t ) t ∈ [ 0 , T ] Classical results on the Hamilton–Jacobi equation with viscosity solution can be found in Bardi and Capuzzo Dolcetta (1997) and Evans (2010). For a review of its recent extensions to more general solution classes and its applications to traffic flow theory, the reader is referred to Aubin et al. (2008), Bressan and Han (2011a,b), Claudel and Bayen (2010a,b), Daganzo (2005), and Friesz et al. (in press). In the next subsection, we will apply the Lax–Hopf formula to obtain an explicit solution representation of (4.25). 4.2 The Lax–Hopf formula The Lax–Hopf formula provides a new characterization of the solution to the scalar conservation law and the Hamilton–Jacobi equation. It was initially introduced by Lax (1957, 1973), then extended by Aubin et al. (2008), Bardi and Capuzzo Dolcetta (1997), Filippov (1988), and applied to traffic flow theory by Claudel and Bayen (2010a,b) and Daganzo (2005). The Lax–Hopf formula is derived from the characteristics equations associated with the Hamilton–Jacobi PDE, which arises from the calculus of variations and classical mechanics. See Evans (2010) for a complete discussion. For the completeness of our presentation, we will review the Lax–Hopf formula for a Hamilton–Jacobi equation with x-independent Hamiltonian, in the context of the following Cauchy problem (initial-value problem). (4.26) ∂ t N ( t , x ) + H ( ∂ x N ( t , x ) ) = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ R × ( 0 , ∞ ) N ( 0 , x ) = g ( x ) x ∈ R Theorem 4.2 The Lax–Hopf formula Suppose H ( · ) is continuous and convex, g ( · ) : R → R is Lipschitz continuous. Then (4.27) N ( t , x ) = inf y ∈ R t · L x - y t + g ( y ) is the unique viscosity solution to the initial-value problem (4.26), where L is the Legendre transformation of H : (4.28) L ( q ) = inf p { H ( p ) - qp } Proof See Evans (2010).□ Remark 4.3 We note that formula (4.27) does not immediately apply to Eq. (4.25). This is because (1) the Hamiltonian H ( · ) is x-independent; (2) (4.26) contains initial condition instead of boundary condition; and (3) the initial datum g(·) is required to be Lipschitz continuous, which is no the case for U(·), since d dt U ( t ) = u ( t ) is unbounded. Effort has been made in the rest of this section to overcome the difficulties described in Remark 4.3. Fortunately, all those problems can be solved by introducing a flow-based conservation law whose primary variable is f(t, x). (4.29) ∂ x f ( t , x ) + ∂ t 1 v 0 f ( t , x ) = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ) f ( t , 0 ) = u ( t ) t ∈ [ 0 , T ] Notice that in the PDE above, the domain of x is [0, L). The PDE in (4.29) is obviously equivalent to (4.19) as long as the boundary point x = L is excluded. Our next step is to apply the formula from Theorem 4.2 to the following Hamilton–Jacobi equation, which is equivalent to (4.29). (4.30) ∂ x N ( t , x ) + 1 v 0 ∂ t N ( t , x ) = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ) N ( t , 0 ) = U ( t ) t ∈ [ 0 , T ] Remark 4.4 Notice that the system (4.30) can be interpreted as an initial value problem by switching the roles of t and x. This technique enables us to apply Theorem 4.2. The next lemma is an application of the Lax–Hopf formula to (4.30), in the case where U(·) is Lipschitz continuous. Lemma 4.5 Assume that U(·) is Lipschitz continuous with Lipschitz constant M. Then the viscosity solution to (4.30) is given by the following. (4.31) N ( t , x ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - x v 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M · t - x v 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ) Proof By assumption, the flow f(t, x)= ∂ t N(t, x) is uniformly bounded by M. Instantiating (4.26) with (4.30), we have H ( p ) = 1 v 0 p p ∈ [ 0 , M ] The Legendre transformation becomes (4.32) L ( q ) = 0 q ⩽ 1 v 0 q - 1 v 0 M q > 1 v 0 Applying formula (4.27) with switched t and x, we readily deduce (4.33) N ( t , x ) = inf τ ∈ R x · L t - τ x + U ( τ ) In view of (4.32), two cases may arise for (4.33): (i) t - τ x ⩽ 1 v 0 . Then (4.33) becomes (4.34) N ( t , x ) = inf τ ⩾ t - x v 0 U ( τ ) = U t - x v 0 The last equality is due to the monotonicity of U(·). (ii) t - τ x > 1 v 0 . Then (4.33) becomes (4.35) N ( t , x ) = inf 0 ⩽ τ < t - x v 0 t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) (4.34) and (4.35) together yield (4.36) N ( t , x ) = min U t - x v 0 , inf 0 ⩽ τ < t - x v 0 t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) It is useful to observe that the left-continuity of U(·) implies inf 0 ⩽ τ < t - x v 0 t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) ⩽ lim τ → ( t - x v 0 ) - t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) = U t - x v 0 We immediately derive from (4.36) that N ( t , x ) = inf 0 ⩽ τ < t - x v 0 t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - x v 0 t - τ - x v 0 M + U ( τ ) The last equality is due to the left-continuity of U(·). This concludes (4.31).□ Remark 4.6 In fact, formula (4.31) has a much simpler interpretation when U(·) is Lipschitz continuous with constant M. In this case, it is always true that the minimum within (4.31) is attained at the right boundary. Thus N ( t , x ) = U t - x v 0 - M t - x v 0 + M t - x v 0 = U t - x v 0 ∀ x ∈ [ 0 , L ) That is, the flow profile at location x ∈[0, L) is a translation of the profile at x =0, which is consistent with the dynamic of the free-flow phase. In addition, by setting x = L −, we have that the cumulative count of vehicles arriving at the queue (if any) by time t is N ( t , L - ) = U t - L v 0 = U ( t - t 0 ) The purpose of invoking the variational expression (4.31) is: (1) to extend it to include the boundary point x = L; (2) to show that (4.31) holds true even if U(·) is not Lipschitz continuous or not continuous at all. To this end, we relax the assumption on U(·) as follows. Definition 4.7 Entering vehicle count The cumulative count of vehicles entering the link is assumed to be a non-decreasing, left-continuous function U ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + , with possibly countably many upward jumps. Remark 4.8 An immediate consequence of the left-continuity is that U(0)=0, even if U(0+)>0. This is easier to see if we extend the domain of U(·) to include the negative axis (−∞,0) and assign U(t)≡0 ∀t <0. If the link inflow u(·) is an integrable function, then the entering vehicle count U ( t ) = ∫ 0 t u ( s ) ds is absolutely continuous. Yet, the assumptions made in Definition 4.7 are much more general: U(·) could be discontinuous and u(·) could be a distribution. Let w(·) be the flow leaving the queue (link exit flow) as defined in (4.17). We define the cumulative exiting vehicle count (4.37) W ( t ) ≐ ∫ 0 t w ( s ) ds which is Lipschitz continuous since w(t)⩽ M. Remark 4.9 The subtlety of the PDE representation of the Vickrey model lies in the cumulative vehicle counts N(t, L−) and N(t, L+) which are not the same quantity. The former is identical to U(t − t 0), which is not necessarily continuous by Definition 4.7; while the latter is identical to W(t) which is Lipschitz continuous. Thus for every t, the solution N(t,·) may have a downward jump across x = L, which indicates the presence of a concentration of mass (dirac delta) at the exit of the link. This is precisely the “point queue”. We deduce from (4.16), (4.17) and (4.37) that (4.38) U ( t - t 0 ) ⩾ W ( t ) , q ( t ) = U ( t - t 0 ) - W ( t ) (4.39) U ( t - t 0 ) > W ( t ) ⇒ d dt W ( t ) = M , for almost every t The next theorem is one of the main results of this paper. It states that the formula for N(t, x) from Lemma 4.5 can be extended to treat discontinuous U(·), and to include the boundary point x = L. As a result, a closed-form solution for W(·) is available. Theorem 4.10 Analytical representation of W(·) Given cumulative entering vehicle count U ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + as in Definition 4.7, the cumulative exiting vehicle count is given by (4.40) W ( t ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] Proof We start by showing the following identity, based on (4.38) and (4.39). (4.41) min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } = min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ - t 0 ) - M τ } t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] According to (4.38), W(τ)⩽ U(τ − t 0). It thus remains to show min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } ⩾ min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ - t 0 ) - M τ } Fix any t ∈[t 0, T + t 0], let Δ t ≐ min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } . We define τ t ∗ to be (4.42) τ t ∗ ≐ inf { t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t : W ( τ ) - M τ = Δ t } Clearly, τ t ∗ ∈ [ t 0 , t ] exists and is unique. In view of the continuity of W(·), we have by (4.42) that W τ t ∗ - M τ t ∗ = Δ t We claim that U τ t ∗ - t 0 = W τ t ∗ . Clearly we only need to prove this claim for τ t ∗ > t 0 since it is always true that U(0)= W(t 0)=0. Let us assume, by contradiction, that U ( τ t ∗ - t 0 ) > W τ t ∗ . Then the left-continuity of U(·− t 0) at τ t ∗ implies there exists δ >0 such that U ( τ - t 0 ) > W ( τ ) , ∀ τ ∈ τ t ∗ - δ , τ t ∗ . By (4.39), we deduce W τ t ∗ - W ( τ ) = ∫ τ τ t ∗ M ds = M τ t ∗ - τ ⇒ W ( τ ) - M τ = Δ t ∀ τ ∈ τ t ∗ - δ , τ t ∗ This yields contradiction to (4.42), thereby the claim is substantiated. Finally, the fact that U τ t ∗ - t 0 = W τ t ∗ leads to min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ - t 0 ) - M τ } ⩽ U τ t ∗ - t 0 - M τ t ∗ = Δ t = min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } proving (4.41). Next, by Lipschitz continuity of W(·), it follows that (4.43) min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } = W ( t ) - M t Therefore, we deduce from (4.43) and (4.41) that W ( t ) = min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { W ( τ ) - M τ } + M t = min t 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ - t 0 ) - M τ } + M t = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t - t 0 ) □ Remark 4.11 Although the above theorem is a consequence of the PDE approach, (4.40) is independent of any spatial variable or any assumption related to the PDE. Such a formula remains true even if t 0 =0. Theorem 4.10 combined with Lemma 4.5 provides a closed-form solution to the H–J Eq. (4.25). The fact that the formula for x ∈[0, L) can be extended to include x = L is non-trivial. Later in Section 5, we will show that the quantity q(t)≐ U(t − t 0)− W(t) where W(t) is given by (4.40) indeed solves the Vickrey’s ODE in the integral sense. The impact of Eq. (4.40) is threefold. (1) The solution W(t) is given in closed-form, providing opportunity for further mathematical analysis that is relatively difficult to conduct based on the ODE. (2) The exit vehicle count W(·) can be computed directly from the entering vehicle count without any intermediate computation of the queue size. (3) The solution given by (4.40) works for very general flow profiles such as the ones in Definition 4.7. In the rest of this section, we establish mathematical properties of the resulting continuous-time solution. Proposition 4.12 Mathematical properties of the solution Given U ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + defined in Definition 4.7, the following three statements hold. (1) The exiting vehicle count (4.44) W ( t ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] is non-negative, non-decreasing and Lipschitz continuous with Lipschitz constant M. (2) The queue size (4.45) q ( t ) = U ( t - t 0 ) - W ( t ) = U ( t - t 0 ) - M ( t - t 0 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] is non-negative. In addition, if U(·) is absolutely continuous then so is q(·). (3) (First-in-first-out) Let the link traversal time of vehicle entering at time t be (4.46) λ ( t ) ≐ t 0 + q ( t + t 0 ) M t ∈ [ 0 , T ] where q(t) satisfies (4.45). Then for any 0 ⩽ t 1 < t 2 ⩽ T (4.47) t 1 + λ ( t 1 ) ⩽ t 2 + λ ( t 2 ) The equality of (4.47) holds if and only if U(t 1 ) = U(t 2 ) and w(t) ≡ M ∀t ∈ [t 0 + t 1 , t 0 + t 2 ]. Proof (1) We start by showing that W(·) is non-decreasing. Fix any t 1, t 2 such that t 0 ⩽ t 1 ⩽ t 2 ⩽ T + t 0, we have W ( t 2 ) - W ( t 1 ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 2 - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 1 - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t 2 - t 1 ) ⩾ - M ( t 2 - t 1 ) + M ( t 2 - t 1 ) = 0 Then the non-negativity of W(·) follows from monotonicity and the fact that W(t 0)=0. In order to show that the right hand side of (4.44) is Lipschitz continuous, we deduce, for any t 0 ⩽ t 1 ⩽ t 2 ⩽ T + t 0, that 0 ⩽ W ( t 2 ) - W ( t 1 ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 2 - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 1 - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t 2 - t 1 ) ⩽ M ( t 2 - t 1 ) (2) The non-negativity of q(·) is obvious from (4.45). Notice that q(·) is the difference of U(·− t 0) and a Lipschitz (hence absolutely) continuous function W(·). Therefore, q(·) will be absolutely continuous provided that U(·) is absolutely continuous. (3) Using (4.45) and (4.46), we equivalently write (4.47) as U ( t 1 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 1 { U ( τ ) - M τ } ⩽ U ( t 2 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 2 { U ( τ ) - M τ } which is always true since U(t 1)⩽ U(t 2) and min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 1 { U ( τ ) - M τ } ⩾ min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 2 { U ( τ ) - M τ } . In order for the equality in (4.47) to hold, one must have U ( t 1 ) = U ( t 2 ) and min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 1 { U ( τ ) - M τ } = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t 2 { U ( τ ) - M τ } The second identity implies the following W ( t 0 + t 2 ) - W ( t 0 + t 1 ) = M ( t 2 - t 1 ) This means that w(t)≡ M ∀t ∈[t 0 + t 1, t 0 + t 2].□ The sufficient and necessary condition provided in (3) implies that if two drivers entering the link at different times were to exit the link at the same time, then (a) there must be no other cars between them and (b) the driver that enters first must wait in a non-empty queue until the second driver catches up with him/her. 5 Explicit solution to the ordinary differential equation In this section, we return to the original system (4.16) and (4.17). Recall the ODE with discontinuous dependence on the state variable q(·): (5.48) dq ( t ) dt = u ( t - t 0 ) - min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) > 0 t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] We assert that the solution derived from the PDE approach indeed solves the ODE above. To make our assertion precise, let us define a proper solution class for the ODE. Definition 5.1 Strong solution of the ODE Given an integrable function u ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + as in (5.48), the strong solution (also called the integral solution) to the ODE (5.48) is defined to be an absolutely continuous function q ( · ) : [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] → R + with q(0)=0, which satisfies (5.48) at almost every t ∈[t 0, T + t 0]. Theorem 5.2 The explicit formula for the queue size q(t) given in Proposition 4.12 (5.49) q ( t ) = U ( t - t 0 ) - M ( t - t 0 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] is the strong solution to the ODE (5.48) in the sense of Definition 5.1. Here the absolutely continuous function U(·) is defined by U ( t ) ≐ ∫ 0 t u ( s ) ds t ∈ [ 0 , T ] Proof Let us define a Lipschitz continuous function with Lipschitz constant M (5.50) W ( t ) ≐ min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] Notice that by definition (5.50), we have U(·− t 0)⩾ W(·). (5.49) becomes q(t)= U(t − t 0)− W(t). It then follows immediately that q(·) is absolutely continuous and d dt q ( t ) = u ( t - t 0 ) - d dt W ( t ) for almost every t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] Notice that the above differentiations are well-defined due to absolute continuity. It remains to show that for almost every t ∈[t 0, T + t 0], (5.51) d dt W ( t ) = min { u ( t - t 0 ) , M } if q ( t ) = 0 M if q ( t ) > 0 We fix any t ∈(t 0, T + t 0]⧹Ω, where Ω is the set of points where U(·− t 0) or W(·) are not differentiable. Notice that Ω has zero measure. Two cases may arise. (i) q(t)=0. Then U(t − t 0)= W(t). By definition (5.50), we have (5.52) U ( t - t 0 ) - M ( t - t 0 ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } We claim that d dt U ( t - t 0 ) - M ( t - t 0 ) ⩽ 0 . Otherwise, consider ε >0 small enough such that d dt U ( t - t 0 ) > M + ε . Then there exists δ >0 such that U ( t - t 0 ) - U ( t 1 - t 0 ) t - t 1 > M + ε ∀ t 1 ∈ [ t - δ , t ) contradicting (5.52). Thereby the claim is substantiated. Next, we show that d dt W ( t ) = d dt U ( t - t 0 ) . Indeed, consider any sequence t n > t ∀ n ∈ N such that t n → t. Recalling W(·)⩽ U(·− t 0), we have W ( t n ) - W ( t ) t n - t ⩽ U ( t n - t 0 ) - U ( t - t 0 ) t n - t ∀ n ∈ N Thus d dt W ( t ) ⩽ d dt U ( t - t 0 ) . We now apply the same argument to any sequence t ν < t ∀ ν ∈ N such that t ν → t, and get d dt W ( t ) ⩾ d dt U ( t - t 0 ) . We conclude that d dt W ( t ) = d dt U ( t - t 0 ) , as promised. We have that d dt W ( t ) = d dt U ( t - t 0 ) = u ( t - t 0 ) . The Lipschitz continuity of W(·) indicates that u(t − t 0)⩽ M. This shows the first case of (5.51). (ii) q(t)>0. In this case, we have U ( t - t 0 ) - M ( t - t 0 ) > min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } By continuity of U(·), there exists a right neighborhood N t + of t such that U ( t ˆ - t 0 ) - M ( t ˆ - t 0 ) > min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } ∀ t ˆ ∈ N t + This implies that W ( t ˆ ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t ˆ - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t ˆ - t 0 ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t ˆ - t 0 ) ∀ t ˆ ∈ N t + Therefore, we take any sequence t n ∈ N t + ∀ n ∈ N with t n → t, and deduce d dt W ( t ) = lim t n → t W ( t n ) - W ( t ) t n - t = M This shows the second case of (5.51).□ 6 The generalized Vickrey model The Vickrey model is based on an ODE formulation (2.7), which requires that the inflow u(·) is an integrable function. Equivalently, the model requires the entering vehicle count U(·) to be absolutely continuous. This assumption however, might be too restrictive for the study of the Vickrey model in the context of analytical dynamic traffic assignment. As demonstrated by Bressan and Han (2011a) and Han et al. (in press), properties of DTA models are better analyzed if the Vickrey model can treat network flow that exists in the distributional sense. To this end, we introduce in this section the generalized Vickrey model. Notice that the formulae in Proposition 4.12 do not require continuity of U(·). In fact, by Definition 4.7, U(·) only needs to be non-decreasing and left-continuous. This suggests a way of extending the Vickrey model to a more general setting without invoking the ODE. In the following definition, we present the GVM for a link which is initially empty. Definition 6.1 The GVM with zero initial condition The generalized Vickrey model is defined in terms of cumulative vehicle counts. Assume the link is empty at t =0. Given the entering vehicle count U ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + , which is non-decreasing and left-continuous. The exiting vehicle count W ( · ) : [ 0 , T ] → R + is then given by (6.53) W ( t ) = 0 t ∈ [ 0 , t 0 ) min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t - t 0 { U ( τ ) - M τ } + M ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ [ t 0 , T + t 0 ] The arc traversal time function λ(·):[0, T]→[0,+∞) is given by (6.54) λ ( t ) = t 0 + 1 M · U ( t ) - Mt - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - M τ } t ∈ [ 0 , T ] In the case where U(·) is absolutely continuous and d dt U ( t ) ≐ u ( t ) , the generalized Vickrey model reduces to the original ODE-based system (4.16)–(4.18). In the GVM, the link inflow is no longer assumed to be a classical function. Rather, it is considered in the distributional sense. 6.1 Initial-boundary value problem We consider the initial-boundary value problem for GVM. Assume that, at time t =0, we are given an initial condition ρ 0(x)∈ L 1[0, L] for the car density on the link, and q 0 ∈ R + for the queue size. Namely, (6.55) ρ ( 0 , x ) = ρ 0 ( x ) x ∈ [ 0 , L ) q ( 0 ) = q 0 This problem is mathematically expressed as the following H–J equation with initial and boundary conditions (6.56) ∂ t N ( t , x ) - min { M ( x ) , - v 0 ∂ x N ( t , x ) } = 0 ( t , x ) ∈ [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ] N ( t , 0 ) = U ( t ) t ∈ [ 0 , T ] N ( 0 , x ) = ∫ x L ρ 0 ( y ) dy + q 0 x ∈ [ 0 , L ] Proposition 6.2 The GVM with initial-boundary conditions Given the initial conditions (6.55) and boundary condition U(·), the cumulative exiting vehicle count W(·) and the arc traversal time function λ(·) are given by (6.57) W ( t ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ¯ ( τ ) - M τ } + M t t ∈ [ 0 , T + t 0 ] (6.58) λ ( t ) = t 0 + 1 M U ¯ ( t + t 0 ) - M ( t + t 0 ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t + t 0 { U ¯ ( τ ) - M τ } t ∈ [ 0 , T ] where U ¯ ( · ) is defined as (6.59) U ¯ ( t ) ≐ 0 t = 0 q 0 + ∫ L - tv 0 L ρ 0 ( y ) dy t ∈ ( 0 , t 0 ] q 0 + ∫ 0 L ρ 0 ( y ) dy + U ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ ( t 0 , T + t 0 ] Proof Let U ∼ ( · ) : [ 0 , T + t 0 ] → R + measure the cumulative number of vehicles that have arrived at the queue. Clearly U ∼ ( 0 ) = q 0 . In addition, during the time interval (0, t 0], the cars initially on the link will arrive at the queue at a rate given by f ( t , L - ) = v 0 ρ 0 ( L - v 0 t ) t ∈ ( 0 , t 0 ] The above identity follows from a simple calculation using method of characteristics, since the dynamic on x ∈[0, L) is governed by a linear advection equation. We have for t ∈(0, t 0], U ∼ ( t ) = q 0 + ∫ 0 t v 0 ρ 0 ( L - v 0 s ) ds = q 0 + ∫ L - v 0 t L ρ 0 ( y ) dy Finally, for the time interval (t 0, T + t 0], the flow arriving at the queue is determined by U(·− t 0). We thus have U ∼ ( t ) = q 0 + ∫ 0 L ρ 0 ( y ) dy + U ( t - t 0 ) t ∈ ( t 0 , T + t 0 ] Notice that we need to pick the left-continuous version of U ∼ ( · ) , which is given by (6.59). Identities (6.57) and (6.58) follow immediately from the definition of the GVM.□ Notice that the left-continuity dictates that U ¯ ( 0 ) = 0 . The formulae would not be correct if one uses U ∼ ( · ) instead. 7 Extension and discussion In this section, we discuss a few extensions of Vickrey model based on the PDE formulation (4.23) and on the GVM. We also discuss the relationship between Vickrey model and the Lighthill–Whitham–Richards model. It turns out that all of these extensions as well as the connection to the LWR model can be made by modifying the capacity function M ( · ) appearing in the PDE representation of Vickrey model: (7.60) ∂ t ρ ( t , x ) + ∂ x min { M ( x ) , v 0 ρ ( t , x ) } = 0 7.1 Piecewise constant M ( x ) In our formulation (4.23), M ( · ) is defined by (4.21). One natural extension is to consider piecewise-constant M ( · ) as a function of x. Such a new PDE could represent dynamics on an inhomogeneous link. It could also account for a network consisting of a series of homogenous links. An example of such a model is presented later in Section 8.2. Eq. (7.60) with piecewise-constant M ( · ) does not admit solutions in the L 1 space. However, the solution does exist in the distributional sense. It is useful to notice that the solution ρ(t, x) for such a system can generate δ-distributions only at location x such that M ( x - ) > M ( x + ) , i.e. wherever there is a drop of capacity. Regarding solution existence and computation, one only needs to solve a problem at a single bottleneck and proceed with induction. For a more detailed discussion of conservation laws with (possibly discontinuous) x-dependence of the flux, the reader is referred to Garavello et al. (2007) and Herty et al. (2007). 7.2 Time-varying flow capacity M(t) We consider the Vickrey model where the flow capacity of the bottleneck is no longer a constant. Instead, it is a (piecewise-constant) function M(·) of time. We may write M ( t , x ) = + ∞ if x ∈ [ 0 , L ) M ( t ) if x = L The resulting conservation law then has a flux function that depends on both t and x. This turns out to be easy to analyze using our explicit formula. Without loss of generality, we consider piecewise-constant M(t) with discontinuities at 0< s 1 < s 2 <⋯< s n . By convention, we let s 0 =0. Define M i ≐ M(t), t ∈(s i−1, s i ). For simplicity, we assume that the free flow travel time t 0 is zero. Let the inflow profile U(·) satisfying Definition 4.7 be given. For the first time interval [s 0, s 1], the cumulative exiting vehicle count and the queue size are simply given by the GVM. (7.61) W ( t ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } + M 1 t t ∈ [ s 0 , s 1 ] (7.62) q ( t ) = U ( t ) - M 1 t - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } t ∈ [ s 0 , s 1 ] We apply Proposition 6.2 to the next time interval [s 1, s 2], with initial queue size q(s 1)= U(s 1)− W(s 1), and inflow profile U ¯ ( t ) = 0 t = s 1 U ( t ) - W ( s 1 ) t ∈ ( s 1 , s 2 ] Given any t ∈(s 1, s 2], the queue size is (7.63) q ( t ) = U ¯ ( t ) - M 2 ( t - s 1 ) - min s 1 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ¯ ( τ ) - M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) } = U ( t ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( t - s 1 ) - min { 0 , min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) } } We distinguish between two cases. (i) min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) } ⩾ 0 . Then (7.64) min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - ( M 1 s 1 + M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) ) } ⩾ min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ s 1 { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } In this case, (7.65) q ( t ) = U ( t ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( t - s 1 ) = U ( t ) - ( M 1 s 1 + M 2 ( t - s 1 ) ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ s 1 { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } Let us define function V(·) to be (7.66) V ( t ) ≐ ∫ 0 t M ( s ) ds t ⩾ 0 By (7.64), there must hold (7.67) min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - V ( τ ) } = min { min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ s 1 { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } , min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - ( M 1 s 1 + M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) ) } } = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ s 1 { U ( τ ) - M 1 τ } Combining (7.65), (7.66) and (7.67), we conclude that q ( t ) = U ( t ) - V ( t ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - V ( τ ) } ∀ t ∈ ( s 1 , s 2 ] (ii) min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) } < 0 . Similarly, we have that q ( t ) = U ( t ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( t - s 1 ) - min s 1 < τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - W ( s 1 ) - M 2 ( τ - s 1 ) } = U ( t ) - V ( t ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - V ( τ ) } ∀ t ∈ ( s 1 , s 2 ] In either case, it holds that (7.68) q ( t ) = U ( t ) - V ( t ) - min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - V ( τ ) } Consequently, (7.69) W ( t ) = U ( t ) - q ( t ) = min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - V ( τ ) } + V ( t ) A simple mathematical induction shows that (7.68) and (7.69) hold for all t ⩾0. The potential cumulative throughput function V(τ) is a generalization of the function M · τ in (6.53). The formulae for the time-dependent flow capacity case have similar structures as the GVM. 7.3 M ( · ) that depends only on density In our final discussion, we recover the LWR model by letting M to depend on density. This allows us to establish the connection between the Vickrey model and the LWR model. Define (7.70) M ( ρ ) = - ω · ( ρ - ρ jam ) 0 ⩽ ρ ⩽ ρ jam where ω and ρ jam are arbitrary positive constants. It is then easy to verify that ϕ ( ρ ) ≐ min { M ( ρ ) , v 0 ρ } coincides with the triangular fundamental diagram. We thus recover the classical LWR PDE ∂ t ρ ( t , x ) + ∂ x min { M ( ρ ( t , x ) ) , v 0 ρ ( t , x ) } = 0 The relationship between the Vickrey model and the LWR model can be interpreted as follows. Both are representable by evolution equation based on conservation of mass. The different is that the Vickrey model explicitly imposes bounds on the flows, whereas the LWR model explicitly imposes bounds on the densities. This can be seen from their respective fundamental diagrams (Fig. 1 ). The Vickrey model bounds the flows, allowing density to be arbitrarily large. Once the density exceeds the critical value M/v 0, a wave with zero speed is created corresponding to a δ-distribution in the density. The LWR model, on the other hand, stipulates that the density cannot exceed ρ jam . Thus when the density reaches the critical value where the flow is maximized, a wave with negative speed is created preventing cars from concentrating at a single location. 8 Example In this section, we provide two examples illustrating the explicit formulae of the GVM and the solution property associated with the Hamilton–Jacobi Eq. (4.25). Notice that in these examples, the choices of link parameters and/or flow patterns are for the simplicity and ease of our presentation. The proposed methodology is capable of handling complex traffic network scenarios, which is partially illustrated in Han et al. (in press). 8.1 Continuous-time solutions In this section, we illustrate the geometric meaning of formula (5.49) as well as other explicit formulae, using a continuous-time example. Without loss of generality, we assume the free flow time t 0 =0. Consider the following inflow profile (8.71) u ( t ) = cos ( t - π ) + 1 , U ( t ) = sin ( t - π ) + t t ∈ [ 0 , 10 ] The key step of computing the GVM is to find min0⩽τ⩽t {U(τ)− Mτ}. In order to understand such a quantity, we provide four different cases with varying flow capacities M =0.5, 1, 1.5, 2. The four cases are depicted in Figs. 2–5 , respectively. (i) M =0.5. Function U(τ)− Mτ has a global minimizer τ ∗ = π/3. U(τ ∗)− Mτ ∗ =−0.3424. We have min 0 ⩽ τ ⩽ t { U ( τ ) - M τ } = U ( t ) - Mt if 0 ⩽ t ⩽ π / 3 - 0.3424 if π / 3 < t ⩽ 10 The solution to the ODE (5.48) reads q ( t ) = 0 if 0 ⩽ t ⩽ π / 3 sin ( t - π ) + 0.5 t + 0.3424 if π / 3 < t ⩽ 10 (ii) M =1. U(τ)− Mτ has two global minimizers τ 1 ∗ = π / 2 and τ 2 ∗ = 5 π / 2 , with minimum value −1. Thus q ( t ) ≡ 0 0 ⩽ t ⩽ 10 Remark 8.1 The above four solutions for queue sizes satisfy the ODE everywhere except case 3. From Fig. 4 we observe that the quantity min0⩽τ⩽t {U(τ)− Mτ} has a kink at point p =5.3876. This renders q(·) not differentiable there. A plot of q(·) confirms the non-differentiability at t =5.3876, see Fig. 6 . 8.2 Three consecutive links In this example, we interpret the Vickrey model from a PDE point of view. As shown in Section 4, the continuous-time Vickrey model can be formulated as a Hamilton–Jacobi equation by introducing an virtual spatial dimension x ∈[0, L], and a free flow speed v 0 such that t 0 = L/v 0. Consider a sequence of three links: e 1, e 2, e 3 with a combined length of 2000m, see Fig. 7 . The parameters of each link are presented in Table 1 . We introduce the cumulative vehicle count N ( · , · ) : [ 0 , T ] × [ 0 , L ] → R + . N(t, x) measures the number of vehicles that have passed location x up to time t. The total length L of this three-arc network is 2000m. As discussed in Section 7.1, the dynamics on the network can be described by the following single H–J equation, along with proper initial and boundary value conditions. (8.72) ∂ t N ( t , x ) - min { M ( x ) , - v 0 ∂ x N ( t , x ) } = 0 Notice that (8.72) has an x-dependent Hamiltonian. The capacity function is given by M ( x ) = 40 x ∈ [ 0 , 667 ] 30 x ∈ ( 667 , 1333 ] 20 x ∈ ( 1333 , 2000 ] The network inflow is shown in Fig. 8 . We denote by U(t) the cumulative entering vehicle count at x =0, i.e. at the entrance of link e 1. PDE (8.72) is readily solved using the techniques mentioned in Section 7.1, with boundary condition N(t,0)= U(t). Fig. 9 shows the function N(t,0)− N(t, x), (t, x)∈[0,20]×[0,2000], which measures the number of vehicles located in the spatial interval [0, x] at time t. Several discontinuities in the function are displayed in Fig. 9, which correspond to the δ-distributions located at the end of links e 1 and e 2, i.e. at x =667 and x =1333. The time-varying magnitudes of these jumps measure the respective sizes of the queues. Fig. 10 shows the flow variable f(t, x) obtained by numerically differentiating N(t, x) with respect to t. 2 Although N(t, x) is discontinuous w.r.t. x, it is Lipschitz continuous w.r.t. t. This is because its time derivative, the flow, is uniformly bounded. This is the unique feature of models that explicitly bound flow instead of density. 2 The plateaus indicate that the flow reaches the capacities of links e 2 and e 3. 9 Conclusion The continuous-time ODE formulation of the Vickrey model is analytically and computationally problematic due to the discontinuous right hand side. So far, most research on the Vickrey model is either discrete-time in nature or relies on a modification of the original one. In this paper, we directly tackle such an ODE problem by reformulating it as a partial differential equation (Hamilton–Jacobi equation). This new formulation allows the Vickrey model to be analyzed in continuous time with well-developed PDE theory and computational paradigms. As a result, the Vickrey ODE with a discontinuous right hand side can be solved in closed form. We start by adding a virtual spatial dimension to the model and by transforming the ODE to a scalar conservation law. Such a conservation law has an x-dependent flux function. We apply a variational method to the corresponding Hamilton–Jacobi equation in search for an explicit solution representation. The resulting closed-form solution is then verified to solve the Vickrey ODE almost everywhere. We further our analysis by providing analytical properties of the solution pertaining to physical realism, regularity and first-in-first-out. We propose the generalized Vickrey model, which extends the current ODE-based model to incorporate flow profiles that are distributions. The GVM is then further generalized to treat arbitrary initial and boundary conditions and to handle road inhomogeneity and time-varying capacity. We conclude the work by offering an interpretation of the relationship between the Vickrey model and the LWR model, based on our PDE formulation. The work presented in this paper provides a new perspective of the Vickrey model by relating it to first-order PDE models such as the LWR model. Such a novel view point enables us to understand the model using more sophisticated mathematical tools, with results including closed-form solution, solution regularity, stability and convergence. Such an approach also facilitates the study of DTA models by providing a new framework of analysis and computation. The work in this paper has already led to a few important findings regarding the network models, which are reported in Han et al. (in press) and Han et al. (2012a). coredata.dc:description: Abstract This paper is concerned with the continuous-time Vickrey model, which was first introduced in Vickrey (1969). This model can be described by an ordinary differential equation (ODE) with a right-hand side which is discontinuous in the unknown variable. Such a formulation induces difficulties with both theoretical analysis and numerical computation. Moreover it is widely suspected that an explicit solution to this ODE does not exist. In this paper, we advance the knowledge and understanding of the continuous-time Vickrey model by reformulating it as a partial differential equation (PDE) and by applying a variational method to obtain an explicit solution representation. Such an explicit solution is then shown to be the strong solution to the ODE in full mathematical rigor. Our methodology also leads to the notion of generalized Vickrey model (GVM), which allows the flow to be a distribution, instead of an integrable function. As explained by Han et al. (in press), this feature of traffic modeling is desirable in the context of analytical dynamic traffic assignment (DTA). The proposed PDE formulation provides new insights into the physics of The Vickrey model, which leads to a number of modeling extensions as well as connection with first-order traffic models such as the Lighthill–Whitham–Richards (LWR) model. The explicit solution representation also leads to a new computational method, which will be discussed in an accompanying paper, Han et al. (in press).
coredata.dc:title: A partial differential equation formulation of Vickrey’s bottleneck model, part I: Methodology and theoretical analysis
